The Not block is the logical not operato: The Not block is the logical not operator.
The And block is the logical and operato: The And block is the logical and operator.
The Or block is the logical or operator.
The XOR block is the logical XOR operato: The XOR block is the logical XOR operator.
The Equal block returns True if the two: The Equal block returns True if the two numbers are equal.
The Not-equal-to block returns True if t: The Not-equal-to block returns True if the two numbers are not equal to each other.
The Boolean block is used to specify tru: The Boolean block is used to specify true or false.
The Add-to block is used to add to the v: The Add-to block is used to add to the value stored in a box.
It can also be used with other blocks su: It can also be used with other blocks such as Color and Pen size.
The Add-1-to block adds one to the value: The Add-1-to block adds one to the value stored in a box.
The Subtract-1-from block subtracts one: The Subtract-1-from block subtracts one from the value stored in a box.
The Box block returns the value stored i: The Box block returns the value stored in a box.
The Store in block will store a value in: The Store in block will store a value in a box.
The Box2 block returns the value stored: The Box2 block returns the value stored in Box2.
The Store in Box2 block is used to store: The Store in Box2 block is used to store a value in Box2.
The Box1 block returns the value stored: The Box1 block returns the value stored in Box1.
The Store in Box1 block is used to store: The Store in Box1 block is used to store a value in Box1.
The Dictionary block returns a dictionar: The Dictionary block returns a dictionary.
The Get-dict block returns a value in th: The Get-dict block returns a value in the dictionary for a specified key.
The Set-dict block sets a value in the d: The Set-dict block sets a value in the dictionary for a specified key.
The Noise name block is used to select a: The Noise name block is used to select a noise synthesizer.
The Drum name block is used to select a: The Drum name block is used to select a drum.
The Effects name block is used to select: The Effects name block is used to select a sound effect.
The Play noise block will generate white: The Play noise block will generate white, pink, or brown noise.
Replace every instance of a pitch with a: Replace every instance of a pitch with a drum sound.
In the example above, a kick drum sound: In the example above, a kick drum sound will be played instead of sol.
You can use multiple Drum blocks within: You can use multiple Drum blocks within a Note block.
The Heap block returns the heap.
The Heap-length block returns the length: The Heap-length block returns the length of the heap.
The Heap-empty? block returns true if th: The Heap-empty? block returns true if the heap is empty.
The Empty-heap block empties the heap.
The Reverse-heap block reverses the orde: The Reverse-heap block reverses the order of the heap.
The Index-heap block returns a value in: The Index-heap block returns a value in the heap at a specified location.
The Set-heap entry block sets a value in: The Set-heap entry block sets a value in he heap at the specified location.
The Pop block removes the value at the t: The Pop block removes the value at the top of the heap.
The Push block adds a value to the top o: The Push block adds a value to the top of the heap.
The Temperament name block is used to se: The Temperament name block is used to select a tuning method.
The Doubly block will double the size of: The Doubly block will double the size of an interval.
You must use two pitch blocks when measu: You must use two pitch blocks when measuring an interval.
The Scalar interval block measures the d: The Scalar interval block measures the distance between two notes in the current key and mode.
In the figure, we add sol# to sol.
The output of the example is: do, mi, so: The output of the example is: do, mi, sol, sol, ti, mi
The Chord block calculates common chords: The Chord block calculates common chords.
In the figure, we generate a C-major cho: In the figure, we generate a C-major chord.
The Ratio Interval block calculates an i: The Ratio Interval block calculates an interval based on a ratio.
In the figure, we add la to sol.
The Mode length block is the number of n: The Mode length block is the number of notes in the current scale.
The Set key block is used to set the key: The Set key block is used to set the key and mode,
The Int block returns an integer.
The Mod block returns the remainder from: The Mod block returns the remainder from a division.
The Power block calculates a power funct: The Power block calculates a power function.
The Sqrt block returns the square root.
The Abs block returns the absolute value: The Abs block returns the absolute value.
The Distance block returns the distance: The Distance block returns the distance between two points. For example, between the mouse and the center of the screen.
The Divide block is used to divide.
The Multiply block is used to multiply.
The Minus block is used to subtract.
The Plus block is used to add.
The One-of block returns one of two choi: The One-of block returns one of two choices.
The Random block returns a random number: The Random block returns a random number.
The Number block holds a number.
The Neighbor block rapidly switches betw: The Neighbor block rapidly switches between neighboring pitches.
The Load-heap-from-app block loads the h: The Load-heap-from-app block loads the heap from a web page.
The Save-heap-to-app block saves the hea: The Save-heap-to-app block saves the heap to a web page.
Cannot find a valid heap for: Cannot find a valid heap for
The Load-heap block loads the heap from: The Load-heap block loads the heap from a file.
The file you selected does not contain a: The file you selected does not contain a valid heap.
The loadHeap block needs a loadFile bloc: The loadHeap block needs a loadFile block.
The Set-heap block loads the heap.
The block you selected does not contain: The block you selected does not contain a valid heap.
The Set heap block needs a heap.
The Load-dictionary block loads a dictio: The Load-dictionary block loads a dictionary from a file.
The file you selected does not contain a: The file you selected does not contain a valid dictionary.
The load dictionary block needs a load f: The load dictionary block needs a load file block.
The Set-dictionary block loads a diction: The Set-dictionary block loads a dictionary.
The block you selected does not contain: The block you selected does not contain a valid dictionary.
The set dictionary block needs a diction: The set dictionary block needs a dictionary.
The Save-heap block saves the heap to a: The Save-heap block saves the heap to a file.
The Save-dictionary block saves a dictio: The Save-dictionary block saves a dictionary to a file.
The Open palette block opens a palette.
The Delete block block removes a block.
The Move block block moves a block.
The Dock block block connections two blo: The Dock block block connections two blocks.
The Make block block creates a new block: The Make block block creates a new block.
The Open project block is used to open a: The Open project block is used to open a project from a web page.
Note value must be greater than 0.
The Skip notes block will cause notes to: The Skip notes block will cause notes to be skipped.
The Tie block works on pairs of notes, c: The Tie block works on pairs of notes, combining them into one note.
An argument of -1 results in a note valu: An argument of -1 results in a note value of 0.
The Dot block extends the duration of a: The Dot block extends the duration of a note by 50%.
Eg a dotted quarter note will play for 3: Eg a dotted quarter note will play for 3/8 (1/4 + 1/8) of a beat.
The Note block is a container for one or: The Note block is a container for one or more Pitch blocks.
The Note block specifies the duration (n: The Note block specifies the duration (note value) of its contents.
The Rhythm block is used to generate rhy: The Rhythm block is used to generate rhythm patterns.
Tuplets are a collection of notes that g: Tuplets are a collection of notes that get scaled to a specific duration.
The Backward block runs code in reverse: The Backward block runs code in reverse order (Musical retrograde).
The Duplicate block will run each block: The Duplicate block will run each block multiple times.
The Default block is used inside of a Sw: The Default block is used inside of a Switch to define the default action.
The Case Block must be used inside of a: The Case Block must be used inside of a Switch Block.
The Case block is used inside of a Switc: The Case block is used inside of a Switch to define matches.
The Switch block will run the code in th: The Switch block will run the code in the matching Case.
The Stop block will stop a loop: The Stop block will stop a loop
The Waitfor block will wait until the co: The Waitfor block will wait until the condition is true.
The Until block will repeat until the co: The Until block will repeat until the condition is true.
The While block will repeat while the co: The While block will repeat while the condition is true.
In this example if the mouse button is p: In this example if the mouse button is pressed a snare drum will play.
The Forever block will repeat the contai: The Forever block will repeat the contained blocks forever.
The Repeat block will repeat the contain: The Repeat block will repeat the contained blocks.
In this example the note will be played: In this example the note will be played 4 times.
The Beats per minute block returns the c: The Beats per minute block returns the current beats per minute.
The Measure count block returns the curr: The Measure count block returns the current measure.
The Beat count block is the number of th: The Beat count block is the number of the current beat,
The Note counter block can be used to co: The Note counter block can be used to count the number of contained notes.
The Whole notes played block returns the: The Whole notes played block returns the total number of whole notes played.
The No clock block decouples the notes f: The No clock block decouples the notes from the master clock.
The On-weak-beat block lets you specify: The On-weak-beat block lets you specify actions to take on weak (off) beats.
The On-strong-beat block lets you specif: The On-strong-beat block lets you specify actions to take on specified beats.
The On-every-beat block lets you specify: The On-every-beat block lets you specify actions to take on every beat.
The On-every-note block lets you specify: The On-every-note block lets you specify actions to take on every note.
The Beats per minute block sets the numb: The Beats per minute block sets the number of 1/4 notes per minute.
The Scalar step down block returns the n: The Scalar step down block returns the number of semi-tones down to the previous note in the current key and mode.
The Scalar step up block returns the num: The Scalar step up block returns the number of semi-tones up to the next note in the current key and mode.
The Change in pitch block is the differe: The Change in pitch block is the difference (in half steps) between the current pitch being played and the previous pitch played.
The Pitch number block is the value of t: The Pitch number block is the value of the pitch of the note currently being played.
The Pitch in Hertz block is the value in: The Pitch in Hertz block is the value in Hertz of the pitch of the note currently being played.
The Current Pitch block is used with the: The Current Pitch block is used with the Pitch Converter block. In the example above, current pitch, sol 4, is displayed as 392 hertz.
This block converts the pitch value of t: This block converts the pitch value of the last note played into different formats such as hertz, letter name, pitch number, et al.
The Set pitch number offset block is use: The Set pitch number offset block is used to set the offset for mapping pitch numbers to pitch and octave.
The Number to pitch block will convert a: The Number to pitch block will convert a pitch number to a pich name.
The Number to octave block will convert: The Number to octave block will convert a pitch number to an octave.
Y to pitch block will convert a staff y: Y to pitch block will convert a staff y position to corresponding pitch notation.
The Accidental selector block is used to: The Accidental selector block is used to choose between double-sharp, sharp, natural, flat, and double-flat.
Pitch can be specified in terms of ni dh: Pitch can be specified in terms of ni dha pa ma ga re sa.
Pitch can be specified in terms of C D E: Pitch can be specified in terms of C D E F G A B.
Pitch can be specified in terms of do re: Pitch can be specified in terms of do re mi fa sol la ti.
The Invert block rotates any contained n: The Invert block rotates any contained notes around a target note.
The Register block provides an easy way: The Register block provides an easy way to modify the register (octave) of the notes that follow it.
The Semi-tone transposition block will s: The Semi-tone transposition block will shift the pitches contained inside Note blocks up (or down) by half steps.
In the example shown above, sol is shift: In the example shown above, sol is shifted up to sol#.
The Transpose by Ratio block will shift: The Transpose by Ratio block will shift the pitches contained inside Note blocks up (or down) by a ratio
The Scalar transposition block will shif: The Scalar transposition block will shift the pitches contained inside Note blocks up (or down) the scale.
In the example shown above, sol is shift: In the example shown above, sol is shifted up to la.
The Accidental block is used to create s: The Accidental block is used to create sharps and flats
The Hertz block (in combination with a N: The Hertz block (in combination with a Number block) will play a sound at the specified frequency.
The Pitch Number block will play a pitch: The Pitch Number block will play a pitch associated by its number, e.g. 0 for C and 7 for G.
nth Modal Pitch takes the pattern of pit: nth Modal Pitch takes the pattern of pitches in semitones for a mode and makes each point a degree of the mode,
starting from 1 and regardless of tonal: starting from 1 and regardless of tonal framework (i.e. not always 8 notes in the octave)
Nth Modal Pitch takes a number as an inp: Nth Modal Pitch takes a number as an input as the nth degree for the given mode. 0 is the first position, 1 is the second, -1 is the note before the first etc.
The pitches change according to the mode: The pitches change according to the mode specified without any need for respellings.
Scale Degree is a common convention in m: Scale Degree is a common convention in music. Scale Degree offers seven possible positions in the scale (1-7) and can be modified via accidentals.
Scale Degree 1 is always the first pitch: Scale Degree 1 is always the first pitch in a given scale, regardless of octave.
The Scalar Step block (in combination wi: The Scalar Step block (in combination with a Number block) will play the next pitch in a scale,
eg if the last note played was sol, Scal: eg if the last note played was sol, Scalar Step 1 will play la.
The Pitch block specifies the pitch name: The Pitch block specifies the pitch name and octave of a note that together determine the frequency of the note.
You are adding multiple oscillator block: You are adding multiple oscillator blocks.
The Duo synth block is a duo-frequency m: The Duo synth block is a duo-frequency modulator used to define a timbre.
The AM synth block is an amplitude modul: The AM synth block is an amplitude modulator used to define a timbre.
The FM synth block is a frequency modula: The FM synth block is a frequency modulator used to define a timbre.
The Partial block is used to specify a w: The Partial block is used to specify a weight for a specific partial harmonic.
Partial weight must be between 0 and 1.
Partial block should be used inside of a: Partial block should be used inside of a Weighted-partials block.
The Harmonic block will add harmonics to: The Harmonic block will add harmonics to the contained notes.
The Distortion block adds distortion to: The Distortion block adds distortion to the pitch.
The Tremolo block adds a wavering effect: The Tremolo block adds a wavering effect.
The Phaser block adds a sweeping sound.
The Chorus block adds a chorus effect.
The Vibrato block adds a rapid, slight v: The Vibrato block adds a rapid, slight variation in pitch.
The Set instrument block selects a voice: The Set instrument block selects a voice for the synthesizer,
eg guitar piano violin or cello.
Import a sound file to use as an instrum: Import a sound file to use as an instrument and set its pitch center.
Upload a sound file to connect with the: Upload a sound file to connect with the sample block.
The Return block will return a value fro: The Return block will return a value from an action.
The Return to URL block will return a va: The Return to URL block will return a value to a webpage.
The Calculate block returns a value calc: The Calculate block returns a value calculated by an action.
The Do block is used to initiate an acti: The Do block is used to initiate an action.
The Arg block contains the value of an a: The Arg block contains the value of an argument passed to an action.
In the example, it is used with the One: In the example, it is used with the One of block to choose a random phase.
The Listen block is used to listen for a: The Listen block is used to listen for an event such as a mouse click.
When the event happens, an action is tak: When the event happens, an action is taken.
The Broadcast block is used to trigger a: The Broadcast block is used to trigger an event.
Each Start block is a separate voice.
It is often used for storing a phrase of: It is often used for storing a phrase of music that is repeated.
The Mouse index heap block returns a val: The Mouse index heap block returns a value in the heap at a specified location for a specified mouse.
The Turtle index heap block returns a va: The Turtle index heap block returns a value in the heap at a specified location for a specified turtle.
The Stop mouse block stops the specified: The Stop mouse block stops the specified mouse.
The Stop turtle block stops the specifie: The Stop turtle block stops the specified turtle.
The Start mouse block starts the specifi: The Start mouse block starts the specified mouse.
The Start turtle block starts the specif: The Start turtle block starts the specified turtle.
The Mouse color block returns the pen co: The Mouse color block returns the pen color of the specified mouse.
The Turtle color block returns the pen c: The Turtle color block returns the pen color of the specified turtle.
The Mouse heading block returns the head: The Mouse heading block returns the heading of the specified mouse.
The Turtle heading block returns the hea: The Turtle heading block returns the heading of the specified turtle.
The Set mouse block sends a stack of blo: The Set mouse block sends a stack of blocks to be run by the specified mouse.
The Set turtle block sends a stack of bl: The Set turtle block sends a stack of blocks to be run by the specified turtle.
The Y mouse block returns the Y position: The Y mouse block returns the Y position of the specified mouse.
The Y turtle block returns the Y positio: The Y turtle block returns the Y position of the specified turtle.
The X mouse block returns the X position: The X mouse block returns the X position of the specified mouse.
The X turtle block returns the X positio: The X turtle block returns the X position of the specified turtle.
The Mouse elapse notes block returns the: The Mouse elapse notes block returns the number of notes played by the specified mouse.
The Turtle elapse notes block returns th: The Turtle elapse notes block returns the number of notes played by the specified turtle.
The Mouse pitch block returns the curren: The Mouse pitch block returns the current pitch number being played by the specified mouse.
The Turtle pitch block returns the curre: The Turtle pitch block returns the current pitch number being played by the specified turtle.
The Mouse sync block aligns the beat cou: The Mouse sync block aligns the beat count between mice.
The Turtle sync block aligns the beat co: The Turtle sync block aligns the beat count between turtles.
The Found mouse block will return true i: The Found mouse block will return true if the specified mouse can be found.
The Found turtle block will return true: The Found turtle block will return true if the specified turtle can be found.
The New mouse block will create a new mo: The New mouse block will create a new mouse.

The Mouse-name block returns the name of: The Mouse-name block returns the name of a mouse.

The Mouse-count block returns the number: The Mouse-count block returns the number of mice.

The Nth-Mouse name block returns the nam: The Nth-Mouse name block returns the name of the nth mouse.

Convert a float to a fraction: Convert a float to a fraction
title: title
The No background block eliminates the b: The No background block eliminates the background from the saved SVG output.
The Show blocks block shows the blocks.
The Hide blocks block hides the blocks.
The Space block is used to add space bet: The Space block is used to add space between blocks.
The Wait block pauses the program for a: The Wait block pauses the program for a specified number of seconds.

heading: 方向

The Scroll XY block moves the canvas.
The Control-point 2 block sets the secon: The Control-point 2 block sets the second control point for the Bezier curve.
The Control-point 1 block sets the first: The Control-point 1 block sets the first control point for the Bezier curve.
The Bezier block draws a Bezier curve.
The Arc block moves the turtle in an arc: The Arc block moves the turtle in an arc.
Value must be within -5000 to 5000 when: Value must be within -5000 to 5000 when Wrap Mode is off.

The Set heading block sets the heading o: The Set heading block sets the heading of the turtle.

The Forward block moves the mouse forwar: The Forward block moves the mouse forward.

The Right block returns the position of: The Right block returns the position of the right of the canvas.
The Left block returns the position of t: The Left block returns the position of the left of the canvas.
The Top block returns the position of th: The Top block returns the position of the top of the canvas.

The Width block returns the width of the: The Width block returns the width of the canvas.
The Height block returns the height of t: The Height block returns the height of the canvas.
The Erase Media block erases text and im: The Erase Media block erases text and images.
The Speak block outputs to the text-to-s: The Speak block outputs to the text-to-speech synthesizer
The Camera block connects a webcam to th: The Camera block connects a webcam to the Show block.
The Video block selects video for use wi: The Video block selects video for use with the Show block.
The Open file block opens a file for use: The Open file block opens a file for use with the Show block.
The Stop media block stops audio or vide: The Stop media block stops audio or video playback.
The To frequency block converts a pitch: The To frequency block converts a pitch name and octave to Hertz.
The Avatar block is used to change the a: The Avatar block is used to change the appearance of the mouse.
The Avatar block is used to change the appearance of the turtle.
The Show block is used to display text o: The Show block is used to display text or images on the canvas.
The Media block is used to import an ima: The Media block is used to import an image.
The Text block holds a text string.
The Grey block returns the current pen g: The Grey block returns the current pen grey value.
The Shade block returns the current pen: The Shade block returns the current pen shade value.
The Color block returns the current pen: The Color block returns the current pen color.
The Pen size block returns the current p: The Pen size block returns the current pen size value.
The Set font block sets the font used by: The Set font block sets the font used by the Show block.
The Background block sets the window bac: The Background block sets the window background color.
The Hollow line block creates a line wit: The Hollow line block creates a line with a hollow center.
The Fill block fills in a shape with a c: The Fill block fills in a shape with a color.
The Pen-up block raises the pen so that: The Pen-up block raises the pen so that it does not draw.
The Pen-down block lowers the pen so tha: The Pen-down block lowers the pen so that it draws.
The Set-pen-size block changes the size: The Set-pen-size block changes the size of the pen.
The Set translucency block changes the o: The Set translucency block changes the opacity of the pen.
The Set hue block changes the color of t: The Set hue block changes the color of the pen.
The Set-shade block changes the pen colo: The Set-shade block changes the pen color from dark to light.
The Set grey block changes the vividness: The Set grey block changes the vividness of the pen color.
The Set-color block changes the pen colo: The Set-color block changes the pen color.
The Input block prompts for keyboard inp: The Input block prompts for keyboard input.
The Input-value block stores the input.
The Loudness block returns the volume de: The Loudness block returns the volume detected by the microphone.
The Click block triggers an event if a m: The Click block triggers an event if a mouse has been clicked.
The Click block triggers an event if a t: The Click block triggers an event if a turtle has been clicked.
The Get red block returns the red compon: The Get red block returns the red component of the pixel under the mouse.
The Get red block returns the red component of the pixel under the turtle.
The Get pixel block returns the color of: The Get pixel block returns the color of the pixel under the mouse.
The Get pixel block returns the color of the pixel under the turtle.
The Cursor Y block returns the vertical: The Cursor Y block returns the vertical position of the mouse.
The Cursor X block returns the horizonta: The Cursor X block returns the horizontal position of the mouse.
The Mouse-button block returns True if t: The Mouse-button block returns True if the mouse button is pressed.
The To ASCII block converts numbers to l: The To ASCII block converts numbers to letters.
The Keyboard block returns computer keyb: The Keyboard block returns computer keyboard input.
Attack value should be from 0 to 100.
Decay value should be from 0 to 100.
Sustain value should be from 0 to 100.
You are adding multiple envelope blocks.
Rolloff value should be either -12, -24,: Rolloff value should be either -12, -24, -48, or -96 decibels/octave.
The Temperament tool is used to define c: The Temperament tool is used to define custom tuning.
Upload a sample and adjust its pitch cen: Upload a sample and adjust its pitch center.
The Meter block opens a tool to select s: The Meter block opens a tool to select strong beats for the meter.
The oscilloscope block opens a tool to v: The oscilloscope block opens a tool to visualize waveforms.
The Custom mode block opens a tool to ex: The Custom mode block opens a tool to explore musical mode (the spacing of the notes in a scale).
The Tempo block opens a metronome to vis: The Tempo block opens a metronome to visualize the beat.
The Arpeggio Widget is used to compose c: The Arpeggio Widget is used to compose chord sequences.
The Pitch drum matrix is used to map pit: The Pitch drum matrix is used to map pitches to drum sounds.

The Pitch slider tool to is used to gene: The Pitch slider tool to is used to generate pitches at selected frequencies.
The Music keyboard block opens a piano k: The Music keyboard block opens a piano keyboard that can be used to create notes.
The Pitch staircase tool to is used to g: The Pitch staircase tool to is used to generate pitches from a given ratio.
The Rhythm Maker block opens a tool to c: The Rhythm Maker block opens a tool to create drum machines.
The Phrase Maker block opens a tool to c: The Phrase Maker block opens a tool to create musical phrases.
You must have at least one pitch block a: You must have at least one pitch block and one rhythm block in the matrix.
The Status block opens a tool for inspec: The Status block opens a tool for inspecting the status of Music Blocks as it is running.
The Synth volume block returns the curre: The Synth volume block returns the current volume of the current synthesizer.
The Master volume block returns the mast: The Master volume block returns the master volume.
